title: How will Ducks' defense handle WSU's 'air raid' attack?
text:
How will Ducks' defense handle WSU's 'air raid' attack? Pete Martini , Statesman Journal 4:31 p.m. PDT October 5, 2015 October 3, 2015; Berkeley, CA, USA; Washington State Cougars head coach Mike Leach (center) instructs quarterback Luke Falk (4) during the second quarter against the California Golden Bears at Memorial Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Kyle Terada-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Kyle Terada-USA TODAY Sports) 2 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The Washington State football team is in its fourth season under coach Mike Leach and his "air raid" offense, and despite struggles this year, the passing game leads the Pac-12. 
That could be trouble for Oregon, which ranks last in the conference in passing defense. 
With a young and struggling secondary, the key for the Ducks against Washington State, a game set for 3 p.m. Saturday at Autzen Stadium, will be putting pressure on quarterback Luke Falk, who is averaging a conference-best 364.8 passing yards per game. 
"Obviously, if you can create pressure with three guys, you can be a lot more multiple, a lot different in the coverage," coach Mark Helfrich said. "And the same can be said for a four-man rush. Anything after that, there's a ton of adjustment, a ton of all those things. That certainly is what has made Mike Leach very successful at what he does and why they do what they do." What the Ducks need to do to salvage the season 
Helfrich said bringing pressure in multiple ways will be crucial for the defense. 
"You have to vary things enough. You have to be standard enough in your own minds, so you play fast and free, and not just constantly thinking about a formation adjustment or a coverage adjustment, whatever that might dictate by coverage," Helfrich said. "And then you have to make the quarterback uncomfortable, whether that's hitting him, pressuring him, confusing him, creating turnovers. Just all those things you have to do to get in their head." 
Washington State opened the season with a 24-17 loss at home to Portland State. After that stunner, Leach was on the hot seat. 
The Cougars responded by beating Rutgers and Wyoming, and after a bye, they almost pulled an upset at California last week, falling 34-28 in Berkeley. 
Washington State almost derailed Oregon's Pac-12 championship last season in Pullman, but the Ducks escaped with a 38-31 victory with Marcus Mariota carrying the team on his way to winning the Heisman Trophy. Helfrich comfortable using two QBs again 'if it makes sense' 
This season, Washington State will need to prepare for multiple quarterbacks. 
Oregon sat graduate transfer quarterback Vernon Adams last week with a broken finger, and played both junior Jeff Lockie and sophomore walkon Taylor Alie. 
Helfrich said Sunday he would be comfortable using multiple quarterbacks again "if it makes sense." 
Washington State ranks ninth in the Pac-12 in points (26.5) and yards (393.5) allowed. 
The Cougars rank sixth in the conference in rushing defense, allowing 155.8 yards per game. However, they haven't seen a rushing attack like Oregon's yet this season. The Ducks lead the conference, averaging 300.4 rushing yards per game. 
Washington State will try to end a couple streaks on Saturday. The last time the Cougars beat the Ducks was in 2006. And the last time they won at Autzen Stadium was in 2003. 
Those are long droughts.
